title: Don Schollander
text:
Donald Arthur Schollander (born April 30, 1946) is an American former competition swimmer, five-time Olympic champion, and former world record-holder in four events. He won a total of five gold medals and one silver medal at the <a href="1964%20Summer%20Olympics">1964</a> and <a href="1968%20Summer%20Olympics">1968 Summer Olympics</a>. With four gold medals, he was the <a href="Lists%20of%20Olympic%20medalists%23Medalist%20with%20most%20medals%20by%20Olympiad">most successful</a> athlete at the 1964 Olympics.
Early career.
Schollander was born in <a href="Charlotte%2C%20North%20Carolina">Charlotte, North Carolina</a>, and learned competitive swimming from his uncle, <a href="Newt%20Perry">Newt Perry</a>, who ran a swimming school in Florida. As a boy, Schollander moved with his family to <a href="Lake%20Oswego%2C%20Oregon">Lake Oswego, Oregon</a>. Although his first sporting passion was <a href="American%20football">football</a>, he was too small to compete in high school football. Instead, he joined <a href="Lake%20Oswego%20High%20School">Lake Oswego High School</a>'s swim team, and in 1960, helped lead the team to an Oregon state swimming championship as a freshman.
Olympics.
As a teenager in 1962, Schollander moved to <a href="Santa%20Clara%2C%20California">Santa Clara, California</a> to train under swim coach <a href="George%20Haines">George Haines</a> of the <a href="Santa%20Clara%20Swim%20Club">Santa Clara Swim Club</a>. Two years later at the age of 18, he won three freestyle events at the <a href="Amateur%20Athletic%20Union">AAU</a> national championships. He made the U.S. Olympic team in two individual events and two relays. Months later, he won four gold medals and set three world records at the <a href="1964%20Summer%20Olympics">1964 Summer Olympics</a>, at the time the most medals won by an American since <a href="Jesse%20Owens">Jesse Owens</a> in 1936. His success helped earn him the <a href="James%20E.%20Sullivan%20Award">James E. Sullivan Award</a> as the top amateur athlete in the United States, and the AP Athlete of the Year, defeating runner-up <a href="Johnny%20Unitas">Johnny Unitas</a> by a wide margin. He was also named <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>'s "<a href="Wide%20World%20of%20Sports%20%28U.S.%20TV%20series%29">Wide World of Sports</a>" Athlete of the Year.
Schollander appeared on an episode of "<a href="To%20Tell%20the%20Truth">To Tell the Truth</a>" immediately after winning his four gold medals.
College and Olympic swimming.
Schollander attended <a href="Yale%20College">Yale College</a> and is a member of <a href="Skull%20and%20Bones">Skull and Bones</a>, a secret society, and the <a href="Delta%20Kappa%20Epsilon">Delta Kappa Epsilon</a> (Phi chapter) fraternity. He was the captain of <a href="Yale%20Bulldogs%20swimming%20and%20diving">Yale's swim team</a>, winning three individual <a href="NCAA%20Men%27s%20Swimming%20and%20Diving%20Championships">NCAA</a> championships. At the <a href="1968%20Summer%20Olympics">1968 Summer Olympics</a>, Schollander won another gold medal in the <a href="Swimming%20at%20the%201968%20Summer%20Olympics">4×200-meter freestyle relay</a>, but finished second in the <a href="Swimming%20at%20the%201968%20Summer%20Olympics">200-meter freestyle</a>, the event that Schollander had considered to be his best. This was the first Olympics in which 200-meter swimming events were part of the competition.
Following the 1968 Olympics, Schollander retired from competitive swimming.
After swimming.
Schollander was inducted into the <a href="International%20Swimming%20Hall%20of%20Fame">International Swimming Hall of Fame</a> at age 19 in 1965. In 1983, he was one of the first group of inductees into the U.S. Olympic Hall of Fame. He is also a member of <a href="Oregon%20Sports%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Oregon Sports Hall of Fame</a>.
In 1971, he published his first book, "Deep Water" (with Duke Savage) chronicling his swimming, his teammates and coaches, and the behind-the-scenes politics of international swimming, especially the Olympic Games. He followed this book in 1974 with "Inside Swimming" (with Joel H. Cohen).
Schollander and his wife Cheryl reside in <a href="Lake%20Oswego%2C%20Oregon">Lake Oswego, Oregon</a>, where he runs Schollander Development, a real estate development company. His gold medals are on display to the public at a <a href="Bank%20of%20America">Bank of America</a> branch location in downtown Lake Oswego. Schollander has three children, Jeb, Kyle and Katie.
